docs.title: Budget App
docs.text:
Welcome to the Budget App documentation.

This application provides a clean, Pythonic way to manage budget categories, track deposits and withdrawals, transfer funds between categories, and visualize spending across categories using a vertical percentage bar chart.

docs.title: 🚀 Features
docs.text:
• Track deposits, withdrawals, and transfers
  • Maintain multiple independent budget categories
  • Validate funds before spending or transferring
  • Generate a clean spending chart with percentage breakdown
  • Command-line interface support
  • No external dependencies

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: This document describes each component of the Budget App.

docs.title: Constructor
docs.text:
Category(name: str)

Creates a new budget category.

docs.title: deposit(amount, description="")
docs.text: Add money to the ledger.

docs.title: withdraw(amount, description="")
docs.text:
Subtract money from the ledger if funds are available.

Returns: - True on success - False if insufficient funds

docs.title: transfer(amount, category)
docs.text: Moves money from one category to another.

docs.title: get_balance()
docs.text: Returns the current total balance.

docs.title: check_funds(amount)
docs.text: Returns True if the amount can be withdrawn; otherwise False.

docs.title: __str__()
docs.text: Returns a formatted ledger display, including category name, entries, and total.

docs.title: 📊 Function: create_spend_chart(categories)
docs.text:
Generates a vertical bar chart showing percentage spending per category.

Arguments: - categories — list of Category objects

Returns a formatted multi-line string ready for printing.

docs.title: Command Line Interface (CLI)
docs.text: The Budget App includes a simple CLI that can generate spending charts directly from the terminal.

docs.title: ▶️ Running the CLI
docs.text:
Use the module execution syntax:

python -m budget_app --chart Food Clothing Entertainment

This command will generate a spend chart for the listed categories.

docs.title: ⚙️ Arguments
docs.text: Flag Description --chart Generates a spend chart with the provided category names

docs.title: 📝 Example
docs.text:
python -m budget_app --chart Food Clothing Auto

This will output a vertical bar chart showing spending (placeholder values if no ledger entries exist yet).

docs.title: ❗ Note
docs.text: The CLI currently creates empty categories using the names provided. To produce charts based on real spending data, use the Python API to populate ledgers in a script.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: This page contains complete examples demonstrating full usage of the Budget App.

docs.title: 📘 Full Workflow Example
docs.text:
from budget_app import Category, create_spend_chart

food = Category("Food")
clothing = Category("Clothing")
auto = Category("Auto")

food.deposit(1000, "initial deposit")
food.withdraw(15.89, "groceries")
food.withdraw(10.15, "snacks")

clothing.deposit(500)
clothing.withdraw(25.55, "shirt")

auto.deposit(1000)
auto.withdraw(100, "repair")

print(food)
print(create_spend_chart([food, clothing, auto]))

docs.title: Usage Guide
docs.text: This guide explains how to use the Budget App to manage financial categories, track transactions, and generate spending charts.

docs.title: 🧱 Creating Categories
docs.text:
from budget_app import Category

food = Category("Food")
clothing = Category("Clothing")
auto = Category("Auto")

Each category maintains its own ledger.

docs.title: ➕ Making Deposits
docs.text:
food.deposit(1000, "initial deposit")
clothing.deposit(200)

docs.title: ➖ Making Withdrawals
docs.text:
food.withdraw(15.89, "groceries")
clothing.withdraw(25.55, "shirt purchase")

If the withdrawal exceeds available funds:

food.withdraw(99999)   # returns False

docs.title: 🔁 Transferring Funds
docs.text:
food.transfer(50, clothing)

Transfers appear in both ledgers:

  • From category: Transfer to Clothing
  • To category: Transfer from Food

docs.title: 📊 Generating a Spending Chart
docs.text:
from budget_app import create_spend_chart

print(create_spend_chart([food, clothing, auto]))

This produces a vertical percentage chart showing how much you've spent in each category.
